name: TheAtlantic
text: "Conventions have long been 'hot'‚Äîloud, unsubtle, the political version of infomercials. The Democrats were forced by the pandemic to be cool, and every political gathering from now on will have to reckon with how effective they were" writes @JamesFallows: https://t.co/Hpx6qMrNK0

name: TheAtlantic
text:

https://t.co/diFsbyFqVD

name: TheAtlantic
text:
RT @ibogost: Every city looks the same now. @Oniropolis explains how it got this way, and why a new commitment to local vernacular style would improve the livability, and sustainability, of global cities.

https://t.co/SJHnSiubhf

name: TheAtlantic
text: For decades, broadcast TV commercials often held the same pop-cultural legitimacy as the programming they ran against. Now they're widely maligned‚Äîand quickly vanishing, @MacSchwerin writes. https://t.co/zhGqOPyXzM

text: "With the planet burning, the virus killing, the economy collapsing, and millions of Americans preparing to vote, the country‚Äôs leading political cabal has moved into a queasy post-policy space," @AnnieLowrey writes: https://t.co/enf2ZSktIY

name: TheAtlantic
text:
TikTok is suing the U.S. government, following Trump‚Äôs executive order against the app.

In July, @MichaelSchuman considered the threat that TikTok poses‚Äînot only to national security, but also to American dominance in the technology sector. https://t.co/v8l1v5r5PP

name: TheAtlantic
text: Jorge Luis Borges was born on this day in 1899. Revisit his 1969 poem, "The Labyrinth," which conjures a surreal, disorienting world. https://t.co/3pJT9WcqjR

name: TheAtlantic
text:

name: TheAtlantic
text: RT @mckaycoppins: Lots of threads to follow this week (and I‚Äôll be covering them!) but maybe the strangest convention subplot is the ongoing fight between Don Jr. and Ivanka to inherit the Trump political dynasty. My story from last year: https://t.co/3LlYIiOnSJ

name: TheAtlantic

name: TheAtlantic
text: "The shooting of Jacob Blake on Sunday in Kenosha, Wisconsin, is at once freshly horrifying and achingly familiar, in the way that only a police shooting in the United States in 2020 can be," @GrahamDavidA writes: https://t.co/CQQy4Sysku

name: TheAtlantic
text:
"It was like all the suffering was invisible to some people. All they could see was crime." 

This week marks 15 years since Hurricane Katrina. In the podcast, "Floodlines," Vann R. Newkirk II explains why the media's focus on looting was a mistake: https://t.co/iHk801uedi https://t.co/f0y9i2jS35
